meta.title: Out with SEO, in with AEO
meta.subtitle: The Case for Range in the Age of Answer Engines
meta.author: Nicholas Galinski
meta.authorBio: Multidisciplinary writer specializing in technical documentation, UX content, and creative storytelling. Former English teacher who brings narrative craft to every form of writing.
meta.heroAlt: A prism showing ideas coming in and various types of story content coming out

meta.excerpt: The skills once dismissed as "support work"—structured authoring, task-oriented writing, semantic clarity—are becoming the foundation of how AI finds and speaks truth.

post.content:
In the corner of a sun-drenched office in Palo Alto, Elena is not trying to go viral.

She is not drafting a LinkedIn post or agonizing over a clever hook. She is working in DITA, tag-loading an XML schema, defining a Task topic for a complex firewall configuration. To a traditional marketing copywriter, her work looks like plumbing. Dry. Rigid. Hidden.

I recognize this work. I have done this work. And I have also done the other work: the landing pages, the brand voice guides, the campaigns built to convert. For years, I thought these were separate careers. One was "technical." The other was "creative." Then the answer engines arrived, and I realized they were always the same career, waiting for the world to catch up.

Outside Elena's four walls, the internet is undergoing a shift that changes whose words get spoken aloud. The blue links we have navigated for thirty years are being replaced by the synthetic, authoritative voice of the Answer Engine. Google's AI Overviews. Perplexity. ChatGPT's browsing mode. Claude. These systems do not want to send users somewhere else. They want to answer the question directly, right now, in their own voice.

And in this new world of Answer Engine Optimization, the content creators best equipped to thrive are not specialists. They are the multidisciplinary ones who learned to move between structure and story, between clarity and persuasion. Content designers. Technical writers. And the marketers who bothered to learn what those disciplines actually do.

What the algorithm wants now

For decades, SEO rewarded a particular kind of writing. You buried the answer to increase time-on-page. You stuffed keywords into headers. You wrote more words than you needed to and twisted language into unnatural helixes to follow whatever the flavor-of-the-month SEO best practice was. The goal was the click. Everything after the click was someone else's problem.

LLMs do not work this way. When ChatGPT or Claude retrieves information from the web, it is not looking for the page most likely to capture attention. It is looking for the chunk most likely to answer the question. Retrieval-Augmented Generation systems break pages into fragments, score them for semantic relevance, and pull the pieces that resolve the query with minimal ambiguity. As Stephen King is quoted in Writer's Digest article The Horror Writer Market and the Ten Bears, "When your story is ready for rewrite, cut it to the bone. Get rid of every ounce of excess fat." In AEO, every word that does not contribute to your marketing story or your audience's end goal is noise. Extra tokens used. Fodder for hallucinations.

This is where content design and technical writing stop being "support functions" and start being the main event.

Why structured content wins

Technical writers have been pre-chunking information for decades. DITA's topic-based authoring creates modular, self-contained units of truth: a Task topic explains how to do something, a Concept topic explains what something is, a Reference topic provides lookup information. Each topic answers one question. Each topic can stand alone. This is not a coincidence. It is the architecture that LLMs now prefer.

Content designers operate under similar constraints. When you write a tooltip, you have one sentence to resolve confusion. When you write an error message, you have three lines to explain what went wrong and how to fix it. Character limits, accessibility requirements, localization constraints. These are not obstacles to good writing. They are training grounds for semantic density. They teach you to say exactly what you mean, with nothing left over.

The skills that felt limiting in the SEO era are now advantages. Bottom Line Up Front is not just a military briefing convention anymore; it is what retrieval systems reward. Controlled vocabularies are not just internal terminology guides; they are what prevent an LLM from confusing your "API key" with your "product key." Schema.org markup is not just technical overhead; it is the metadata that tells machines what your content actually represents.

The content creators who can move between technical precision, content design clarity, and marketing persuasion are not unfocused. They are building range. And range is what the AEO era rewards.

The shift in identity

SEO and AEO are not the same thing. One optimizes for clicks. The other optimizes for answers. That distinction will define who gets cited and who gets ignored.

Concept SEO Mindset AEO Mindset
The Goal Capture a click Resolve an intent
The Unit The Page The Topic (Chunk)
The Metric Time-on-page Time-to-answer, Accuracy
The Strategy Backlinks and hype Structure and semantics

Technical writers and content designers have always known that structure is the foundation of trust. They have always known that the user's need is more important than the brand's story. The industry is catching up to what these disciplines understood all along: clarity is not the absence of style. It is the presence of respect for the reader's time.

But here is the part that matters for your career: knowing one discipline is not enough.

The multidisciplinary advantage

A pure technical writer who has never thought about marketing will produce documentation that is accurate, structured, and invisible. It will sit in a help center, correctly answering questions that no one can find. A pure marketer who has never learned content design will produce campaigns that are engaging, shareable, and semantically hollow. LLMs will read those pages, get confused by the narrative indirection, and cite someone else's documentation instead.

The content creators who thrive in the AEO era will be the ones who can do both. They will understand how to structure information so machines can retrieve it. They will understand how to write interface copy that resolves doubt in a single line. And they will understand enough about marketing to know how to position that content where it matters.

This is not a new argument. I wrote in a previous post that the writers who can move between modes are not dilettantes. They are developing range. The AEO era makes that range economically legible. The skills that used to be filed under "support" are now the skills that determine whether your company's voice is the one the machine chooses to speak.

What this means in practice

You already know how to write under constraint. You know the discipline of the single sentence. The next step is learning structured authoring: how to think in topics, how to map content to schemas, how to make your work machine-readable at the metadata level.

Your edge: Character limits trained you in semantic density. That same compression is what retrieval systems reward.

You already know how to structure information for retrieval. You know DITA, or Markdown with YAML front matter, or API documentation patterns. The next step is learning content design principles: how to write for interfaces, how to handle error states, how to compress meaning without losing clarity.

Your edge: Topic-based authoring is what LLMs want. You have been pre-chunking content for machines before machines knew they needed it.

The path is longer but the opportunity is real. Learn what content designers actually do. Understand why a technical writer uses a controlled vocabulary. Stop thinking of documentation as a cost center and start thinking of it as the raw material that AI will synthesize into your brand's public voice.

Your edge: You understand positioning and audience. Now learn to position content for machines, not just humans.

Skills that compound in the AEO era:

  • Topic-based authoring (DITA, structured Markdown, component content)
  • Schema markup (JSON-LD, Schema.org, RDFa)
  • Microcopy and UX writing (error messages, tooltips, empty states)
  • Taxonomy and controlled vocabulary management
  • Content modeling and information architecture

The quiet authority

Elena finishes her DITA map. She has not written anything that will trend on LinkedIn. She has not crafted a hook designed to stop the scroll. She has defined, with precision, how to configure a firewall in a way that a machine can parse, a user can follow, and an LLM can cite.

Somewhere, a user will ask an AI how to secure their network. The AI will search, retrieve, synthesize. And when it speaks, it will speak in a voice shaped by Elena's work. Not because her content was the most engaging. Because it was the most trustworthy. Because it was structured to be understood.

That is the new authority. Not the loudest voice, but the clearest one. Not the most clicks, but the most accurate answer. If you have spent years learning to write with structure, with constraint, with the user's task in mind, you were not doing support work. You were building the infrastructure the future runs on.
